question.body: Which of the following structure is designed to facilitate the exchange of gasses and nutrients?

response.feedback: Incorrect. Arterioles determine delivery to tissues by constricting or dilating as necessary.
Incorrect. Metarterioles are associated with precapillary sphincters that can be used to direct the flow of blood into specific capillary networks.
Correct. Capillary walls consist of only a tunica interna, which allows for efficient diffusion.
Incorrect. Some post capillary venules can participate in gas exchange, but the main function of the venules is to return the blood to the heart.

question.body: Arterioles can adjust their diameter in response to __________.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Although the sympathetic nervous system is an important determinant of arteriolar diameter, it is not the only determinant of arteriolar diameter on this list as well.
Incorrect. Although several hormones affect arteriolar diameter, there are other determinants of arteriolar diameter on this list as well.
Incorrect. Although local signaling molecules can affect arteriolar diameter, there are other determinants of arteriolar diameter on this list as well.
Correct. Arteriolar diameter can be adjusted in response to many signals, including the sympathetic nervous system, hormones and local signaling molecules.

question.body: Which of the following type of capillary is not matched with its correct description?

multiple_choice.choice: Fenestrated capillary: have large openings, making them the most permeable of all the capillary types
Sinusoid capillaries: allow for the passage of blood cells and blood proteins and are found in bone marrow and liver
Continuous capillary: have the lowest permeability and are found in tissues such as muscle and nervous

response.feedback: Correct. Fenestrated capillaries have openings, but they are not as large as those in sinusoid capillaries. Therefore, they are not the most permeable capillaries.
Incorrect. This is an appropriate description of sinusoid capillaries.
Incorrect. This is an appropriate description of continuous capillaries.
